info.game_comments:
2013 Teen Tournament final game 1.
Leonard Cooper becomes the first tournament finalist by rule after the second semifinal game ended without a winner.

(1, 1).clue: Don't walk on the brass "M" on the diag before your first test at this Ann Arbor school; legend says you'll flunk it if you do

(2, 1).clue: Like Rome, this Portuguese capital was built on 7 hills

(3, 1).clue: Born in Wales, he's the first British actor to play Batman on the big screen

(4, 1).clue: A customary mode of personal hygiene was scraping these with a hazel twig & rubbing with a woolen cloth

(5, 1).clue: First name of Mr. Lightyear, or a sound made by a bee

(6, 1).clue: Oregon track coach Bill Bowerman, a founder of this co., said, "if you have a body, you are an athlete"

(1, 2).clue: Volunteer as a test subject at this Cornhusker school that created the first undergraduate psychology lab

(2, 2).clue: Landmarks in this capital include GUM department store & the bell tower of Ivan the Great

(3, 2).clue: He's seen here, the year he got his current show; politics hasn't aged him quite as much as it ages politicians

(4, 2).clue: Played by the Scots before battle, this instrument was easy to make as long as you had a goat or sheep skin & a reed pipe

(5, 2).clue: Kerchoo is a word to represent this

(6, 2).clue: This brand makes the all star quilted canvas flag

(1, 3).clue: No bull! head to this Durham U. to see Cameron Indoor Stadium, conceived in 1935 on the back of a matchbook cover

(2, 3).clue: This central American capital was named for its patron saint, Joseph

(3, 3).clue: In 2012 Demi Lovato & this superstar joined "The X Factor" as judges for season 2

(4, 3).clue: This torture device that stretched & dislocated parts of you was known as the Duke of Exeter's daughter

(5, 3).clue: Boo's sibilant friend, this 4-letter word can express disapproval

(6, 3).clue: In 2012 Derrick Rose of this Midwest NBA team signed a $250 million contract to endorse adidas

(1, 4).clue: Know that this college in Boston was named for founding president Charles W., not writer Ralph W.

(2, 4).clue: This capital of Nepal was once an independent principality

(3, 4).clue: Before making it big on screen as Jacob Black, he was big into martial arts & was a junior world champion

(4, 4).clue: Imported from the Chinese, these rings hung from a saddle allowed a knight to set his feet when spearing an enemy

(5, 4).clue: A noise a bomb might make, it can also refer to a period of rapid economic growth

(6, 4).clue: This brand named for a gazelle goes back to a company that made shoes for 1924 Olympic athletes

(1, 5).clue: Be impressed that the $1 million given in 1873 to endow this U. was the Commodores only major philanthropy

(2, 5).clue: Canals & Dutch architecture can still be seen in this city on the island of Java

(3, 5).clue: Fresh from "Journey 2: The Mysterious Island", he starred as Peeta in "The Hunger Games"

(4, 5).clue: Medieval French poets went on at epic length about chivalry in poems called these "de geste"

(5, 5).clue: The sound of eating a chip, it comes before "time" to mean a moment of pressure

(6, 5).clue: This "quick as a cat" company boasts the Bolt Faas 400 shoe, "inspired by the world's fastest man"

(1, 1).clue: English blacksmith Thomas Newcomen developed this type of engine, constructing one in 1712

(3, 1).clue: In 2007 this former VP won the Nobel Peace Prize, sharing it with the intergovernmental panel on climate change

(4, 1).clue: To repeat a piece of poetry before an audience

(5, 1).clue: If you are asked to keep something secret, you've been told "in" this, also a word meaning "self-assurance"

(6, 1).clue: 2012 brought online gamers a deluxe "Mists of Pandaria" digital download expansion of this game

(1, 2).clue: In 1783 Antoine Lavoisier named this element, from Greek words for "water former"

(2, 2).clue: Galatians: "Christ is become of no effect unto you... ye are fallen from" this

(3, 2).clue: In 1869 Elizabeth Cady Stanton & this woman formed the national woman suffrage association

(4, 2).clue: Falling products of condensation in the atmosphere

(5, 2).clue: During World War II, this girl & her sister Margot lived in a secret annex

(6, 2).clue: His song "Home" downloaded huge after he won "American Idol" in 2012

(1, 3).clue: This polio-vaccine developer established a research facility in San Diego that's named for him

(2, 3).clue: Matthew 6 says, "Consider" these flowers "of the field, how they grow"

(3, 3).clue: In 1959, he gave up the title of chairman of the People's Republic of China but kept control of the country

(4, 3).clue: A car starts to do this--lower in value due to wear & tear--the second it leaves the lot

(5, 3).clue: This law enforcement division was created in 1865 to fight counterfeiting

(6, 3).clue: One of 2011's top nonfiction kindle downloads was "Inside" this: "The Story of America's Most Secretive Religion"

(1, 4).clue: In the 1930s this Caltech seismologist devised a way to determine the magnitude of earthquakes

(2, 4).clue: In Luke, a father celebrates the safe return of an errant son by killing this; "let us eat, and be merry"

(3, 4).clue: Singular last name of Zebulon, who got a Colorado peak named for him without ever reaching the top

(4, 4).clue: To make a return as for something given, like a favor

(5, 4).clue: In a book by Frances Hodgson Burnett, Mary Lennox finds a key that she hopes will open this title place

(6, 4).clue: One mouthwatering iPhone app was this food-cutting game featuring the wise sensei

(1, 5).clue: "Reaching for the Stars" is a biography of this rocket scientist, the son of a German baron

(2, 5).clue: In this Old Testament book, the handwriting on the wall read, "mene, mene, tekel, upharsin"

(3, 5).clue: Brutus called this man, his co-conspirator, "the last of the Romans"

(4, 5).clue: Superficially pleasing or plausible; it describes some arguments

(5, 5).clue: This anti-immigrant party that peaked in the 1850s grew out of a secret society

(6, 5).clue: You can download a podcast of the Kokua Festival started by this Hawaiian singer-surfer-songwriter

(0, 0).clue: In the 1st chapter of this 1939 novel, "When the night came again it was black night, for the stars could not pierce the dust"
